body:
Comment 1: 
I don't see how this could be better. In the func case the name 'f' is
defined, and is a func, so a more specific error is given (that is, it
means f is defined, just not a type). In this case, the name 'f' really is
undefined. This isn't C++: you can't use f to refer to method or field
names when inside a method body.

Of course, we could change the compiler to detect this case, where a method
name was used, inside its own body, as a type name. But I have no idea why
anyone would do that, so I cannot imagine that it is a common enough case
to warrant special code.

Russ
_Status changed to **WorkingAsIntended**._
